name: Internal Medicine - General (Outpatient + Inpatient)

points: High patient volumes with limited appointment time per visit
Excessive panel sizes reducing ability to deliver comprehensive care
Limited administrative or MA support for rooming, refills, and paperwork
Hospitalist workloads exceeding sustainable daily encounters
Short turnaround between discharges, admits, and follow-up responsibilities
Documentation overload and after-hours charting (“pajama time”)
Frequent EMR clicks, inbox management, and prescription refill queues
Multiple EHR transitions or poorly integrated systems across hospital and clinic
Time-consuming prior authorizations and insurance paperwork
Quality metrics and coding demands reducing focus on patient care
RVU-based pay not aligned with panel complexity or time spent per patient
Bonuses tied to quality metrics that are difficult to influence directly
Opaque compensation formulas and lack of transparency in incentive plans
Hospitalist shifts or nocturnist premiums not reflecting intensity of workload
Discrepancy between inpatient and outpatient pay for similar time commitments
Long days with charting spilling into evenings or weekends
Limited flexibility for part-time or 4-day workweeks
Excessive call or weekend coverage in smaller practices
Difficulty taking uninterrupted vacation due to patient continuity concerns
Burnout driven by administrative overload and emotional fatigue
Insufficient staffing (RNs, MAs, front office) leading to inefficiency
Lack of integrated behavioral health or care coordination support
Limited access to subspecialists or diagnostic testing in community settings
Inconsistent rounding or handoff systems for hospitalist teams
Pressure to see more patients without operational investment

motivations: More sustainable patient volumes and manageable panel size
Protected administrative time and improved documentation support
Greater work-life balance with predictable schedules and reduced call
Transparent compensation plans tied to fairness and achievable metrics
Strong nursing and ancillary staff support to improve efficiency
Access to integrated behavioral health and care coordination resources
Geographic relocation for family or lifestyle reasons
Hybrid or hospitalist model with clear expectations and continuity plans
Opportunity for leadership (Chief of Medicine, Quality, or Medical Director roles)
Culture that values quality over quantity and physician well-being
Opportunities for teaching residents or medical students
Employer investment in updated technology, EHR optimization, and workflow tools

opening: Tell me about your current practice setup—outpatient, inpatient, or a mix of both?
What’s motivating you to explore new opportunities at this point in your career?
What are the key changes you’d like to see in your next position?
painDiscovery: You mentioned [pain point]—walk me through how that impacts your day-to-day schedule.
Where do you feel the biggest inefficiencies—in staffing, scheduling, or support systems?
How has EMR workload affected your time with patients or family?
What kind of administrative or documentation support would make your job more sustainable?
If you could change one aspect of your current setup, what would it be and why?
clinical: What’s your typical daily patient volume and ideal target?
Do you manage chronic care panels or primarily focus on acute visits?
For inpatient or hybrid roles, what’s your average daily census and shift structure?
How do you prefer to structure call coverage and patient handoffs?
What support staff ratios (MAs, RNs) help you function most effectively?
What’s your comfort level with procedures (joint injections, paracentesis, central lines, etc.)?
Are teaching or leadership opportunities important to you in your next position?
How do you prefer to collaborate with specialists and care coordination teams?
motivation: When you picture your ideal internal medicine practice, what stands out?
What balance between clinical and administrative work feels sustainable for you?
Which is most important—schedule predictability, compensation, or patient continuity?
What would make a new opportunity feel like a clear improvement over your current role?
compensation: Walk me through your current compensation model—base, wRVU, bonuses, and benefits.
How do you feel about your current balance of compensation versus workload?
What structure—salary, RVU-based, or hybrid—would feel most fair and motivating?

commonChallenges.challenge: I’m burned out from excessive charting and EMR time.
commonChallenges.response: What EMR tools or support (scribes, templates, automation) would meaningfully reduce that burden for you?

commonChallenges.challenge: My patient volume is too high to deliver quality care.
commonChallenges.response: What panel size or daily volume feels sustainable without sacrificing quality?

commonChallenges.challenge: Compensation doesn’t reflect my workload or complexity.
commonChallenges.response: What metrics or structure—RVUs, quality bonuses, or hybrid—would better align with your effort?

commonChallenges.challenge: I’m looking for better work-life balance.
commonChallenges.response: What schedule model—4-day week, reduced call, or hybrid—would create that balance for you?

commonChallenges.challenge: We’re short-staffed and it’s affecting patient care.
commonChallenges.response: What support ratios (MAs, RNs) or operational investments would make the biggest difference in your day?

commonChallenges.challenge: I don’t feel heard by administration.
commonChallenges.response: What kind of leadership culture or communication structure would make you feel more supported?

challengingOpportunities: You mentioned wanting fewer hours—if we structured your schedule around protected admin time or 4-day weeks, would that achieve your goal?
You prefer outpatient-only—if a hybrid model offered predictable rounding and shared call, would that balance your needs?
If compensation is a top priority, would a wRVU plan with guaranteed base plus quality bonuses appeal to you?
If burnout is the main driver, would strong ancillary support and EHR optimization tools make a meaningful difference?
